questions.text: E.histolytica trophozoites multiplies by:
questions.solution: Option A - Protozoa reproduce by asexual and sexual methods. Asexual method like binary fission, multiple fission and endodyogeny. E.histolytica, Leishmania and Trypanosomes multiplies asexually by binary fission. Plasmodia multiplies by multiple fission (Schizogony). Some protozoa like Toxoplasma multiply by internal budding (Endodyogeny).

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the outpatient clinic with complaints of a persistent cough for the past 3 weeks, along with fever, night sweats, and general fatigue. He reports a gradual onset of symptoms, with the cough initially being dry but now productive with occasional blood-tinged sputum. Microscopy reveals following. What is the causative agent.
questions.solution:
• The above features of persistent cough for the past 3 weeks, along with fever, night sweats, and general fatigue and microscopy features of figure of 8 appearance points towards diagnosis of Histoplasmosis.
  • Histoplasmosis is a systemic granulomatous disease caused by a dimorphic fungus, Histoplasma capsulatum.
  • The species name is a misnomer as it is not capsulated. It was first reported by Samuel Darling (1905), hence is also known as Darling's disease.
  • Also known as ohio disease/darling disease/cave's disease.
  • Causes Reticuloendotheliosis
  • Reservoir: bat/bird droppings
    • Contaminated the soil and passed on to the humans.
  • Presentations are similar to TB.
  • Identification:
    • Tuberculate macroconidia using the stain Lactophenol cotton blue yeast-2-4 micron.
  • Paracoccidioidomycosis (also known as South American blastomycosis, Lutz-Splendore-de Almeida disease) it causes Lutz mycosis
  • Coccidioidomycosis (also called desert rheumatism or Valley fever or California fever, San Joaquin valley fever)
  • Blastomycosis (also known as North American blastomycosis or Gilchrist's disease or Chicago disease)

questions.text: True statement regarding Schultz dale phenomenon is:
questions.solution:
• Schultz dale phenomenon is a method for demonstrating anaphylactic hypersensitivity outside the body by suspending an excised intestinal loop or uterine strip from a sensitized animal in an oxygenated, physiological salt solution; addition of the proper allergen causes contraction of the smooth muscle.
  • Examples of Type I Hypersensitivity:
    • Experiments:
      • P-K reaction
      • Schultz Dale phenomenon
      • Theobald smith phenomenon
    • Systemic anaphylaxis
    • Localized anaphylaxis (atopy) such as:
      • Allergic rhinitis (or hay fever)
      • Asthma
      • Food allergy
      • Atopic urticarial
      • Atopic dermatitis (allergic eczema)
      • Drug allergy
      • Wheal and flare reaction.
    • Parasitic diseases:
      • Tropical Pulmonary Eosinophilia (TPE)
      • Loeffler's pneumonia (Ascaris)
      • Ground itch (Hookworm)
      • Leakage of hydatid fluid
      • Cercarial dermatitis/swimmer's itch (Schistosoma).
    • Parasitic tests:
      • Casoni test (hydatid disease)

Incorrect option:

Option b - test to detect atopy to detect atopy we use - skin prick test Radio-immunosorbent test (RIST): It quantitatively detects the total serum IgE Radio-allergic-sorbent test (RAST): It quantifies the serum level of allergen specific IgE

Option c - Whenever there are antibodies against cellular receptors, that is known as a type 5 Hypersensitivity Reaction Myasthenia GRAVIS & Grave's Disease are examples of Type 5 Hypersensitivity Reaction Grave's disease is antibodies against TSH receptors Myasthenia is antibodies against ACh (Acetylcholine) receptor

Option d-test for allergic contact dermatitis is Patch test

questions.text: A 40 yearold female came with complaints of burning in chest and bloating since 2 months. Doctor advised rapid urease test(rut). The rapid urease test (rut) is a popular diagnostic test for:
questions.solution:
Even though other organisms are urease positive here, RUT is not rapid diagnostic test for them

The rapid urease test (RUT) is a popular diagnostic test for diagnosis of Helicobacter pylori. It is a rapid, cheap and simple test that detects the presence of urease in or on the gastric mucosa. It is also known as the CLO test (Campylobacter-like organism test). This test uses a procedure called gastric endoscopy and biopsy to collect stomach lining cells.

  • The test is performed at the time of gastroscopy. A biopsy of mucosa is taken from the antrum of the stomach, and is placed into a medium containing urea and an indicator such as phenol red. The urease produced by H. pylori hydrolyzes urea to ammonia, which raises the pH of the medium, and changes the colour of the specimen from yellow (NEGATIVE) to red (POSITIVE).
  • The test can also be used to provide an informal assessment of the accuracy of the histopathology result and discrepancies should prompt a review of the histopathology and discussions with the pathologist.

Option a:

Klebsiella pneumoniae/Friedlander's bacillus

  • Causes pneumonia
  • Lactose fermenter - pretty pink colour
  • Klebsiella will be capsulated so it will show mucoid colony, String test positive

Option b;

Cryptococcus neoformans

Affect: Usually whole body, but it affects the brain more (Meningitis).

  • Most cases have cryptococcal meningitis.

Stain Tests; CSF Sample: Negative Stain (India Ink/Nigrosin) - mainly used to identify organism.

  • Biopsy: Mucicarmine.

Culture Media Tests

SDA: Shows mucoid colony (due to capsule).

Niger or bird or caffeic seed agar: Gives brown colour (due to melanin due to phenol oxidase/laccase).

questions.text: The difference between Gram positive and gram negative bacterium is that the latter contains:
questions.solution:
• Each peptidoglycan layer is mucopeptide (murein) chain composed of alternate subunits of N-acetyl muramic acid (NAM) and N-acetyl glucosamine (NAG) molecules. It is present in both Gram positive and negative bacteria.
  • Teichoic acid are polymers of ribitol or glycerol joined by phosphate groups. They are present in Gram positive bacteria.
    • Cell wall teichoic acid: Covalently linked to NAM of cell wall.
    • Lipoteichoic acid: attached to lipids of cell membrane
  • Aromatic and sulphur containing aminoacids are present in Gram negative bacteria.

questions.text:
What are the controls used for given image?

A) Bacillus subtilis
b) Bacillus pumilus
c) Bacillus atrophaeus
d) Bacillus globigii
e) Clostridium tetani
questions.solution:
GIVEN IMAGE IS A HOT AIR OVEN

HOT AIR OVEN:

  • it is used at temp 160 degree celsius for 2 hrs
  • it is used for
    • Glassware
    • Cotton swab
    • Dusting powder and liquid paraffin
    • Oil and greasy material

Controls of hot air oven are

  • Biological (bacillus subtilis, bacillus atrophaeus, clostridium tetani)
  • Chemical (browne tube)

Controls used for other methods of sterilization

  • Autoclave/plasma sterilization - b. Stearothermophilus
  • Filtration- brevundimonas diminuta, serratia
  • Radiation- b. Pumilus
  • Gas sterilization - b. Gloigii

choices.text: C2 and C4 normal, C3 is decreased
C3 normal and C2, C4 decreased
C2, C4, C3 all are elevated

questions.text: Which of the following best represents classical complement pathway activation in immuno-inflammatory condition?
questions.solution: In classical complement pathway activation complement levels are decreased because of their utilization in immune-inflammatory conditions.

questions.text: Intracellular survival of listeria monocytogenes is mediated by:
questions.solution:
Pathogenesis of listeriosis:

  • Intracellular survival: After entry into the intestinal epithelium, it survives inside the host cell, mainly due to lysis of phagosome by forming pores (mediated by listeriolysin O)
  • Then it causes host cell actin polymerization, which helps the bacterium to reach near the cell membrane.
  • Finally, it migrates to the adjacent epithelial cells/macrophages by direct cell-to-cell spread, mediated by listeriopods.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male, Ramesh, presented with a complaint of dysuria and painful rashes on his penis, shown in the image below. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
In picture we can see multiple tiny vesicles which are painful on penis, so it could be herpes.

  • The image on correlating with history is suggestive of a STD by Herpes simplex virus.
  • Genital lesions are common in HSV2 infection, which are bilateral, painful, multiple, tiny, vesicular lesions.
  • Associated fever and inguinal lymphadenopathy may also be seen.
  • Incorrect option;

A, c, & D are painful lesions.

Approaching a case of STD (Keywords):

  • Painful lesions: Herpes simplex, Hemophilus Ducreyi.
  • Painless lesions: Treponema palladium, Klebsiella granulomata, Chlamydia serovar L1-3
  • Vesicles: Herpes simplex
  • Groove sign: Chlamydia serovar L1-3
  • Pseudo-bubo: Klebsiella granulomata.

questions.text: Which of the following is a single stranded DNA virus?
questions.solution:
• Parvovirus is the only single stranded DNA virus, while all other DNA viruses are double stranded.
  • Parvoviruses are the smallest viruses, icosahedral in shape and non-enveloped.
  • Parvovirus is transmitted most commonly by respiratory route, followed by blood exchange and transplacental route.
  • Parvovirus infects red cell progenitors - attacks P antigen of RBC.

Conditions associated with parvovirus B19:

  • Fifth day disease/Erythema infectiosum - shows slapped cheek appearance
  • Macular erythematous rash present on cheek
  • Lacy rash on rest of the body
  • Self- limiting
  • Prodrome: fever, sore throat
  • Gloves and stocks syndrome
  • Arthritis and arthralgia
  • Pure Red Cell Aplasia - associated with Thymoma
  • Aplastic crisis (in haemolytic anaemia parvovirus B19) - Haemolytic crisis is associated with EBV.

Non-immune Hydrops Fetalis

Classification of viruses

  • DNA viruses
    • Hepadnaviridae: HBV
    • Herpesviridae: HSV, HZV, EBV, CMV, HHV
    • Adenoviridae: adenovirus
    • Poxviridae: smallpox, cowpox-variola, vaccinia, molluscum
    • Papovaviridae: HPV, BL, JC, Polyoma, Sv40
    • Parvoviridae: parvovirus

Mnemonic: HAPPy

  • RNA viruses
    • Picornaviridae
    • Paramyxoviridae
    • Caliciviridae
    • Togaviridae
    • Orthomyxoviridae
    • Bunyaviridae
    • Flaviviridae
    • Arenaviridae
    • Coronavirodae
    • Reoviridae
    • Rhabdoviridae
    • Retroviridae
    • Filoviridae

questions.text: A patient with HIV presents to the dermatology OPD with the following finding. The patient also complains of Fever, chills, malaise, night sweats, anorexia, and weight loss. Skin biopsy shows capillary proliferation and neutrophilic inflammation. Which of the following bacteria is implicated in this disease?
questions.solution:
• The given image, along with a history of HIV suggests BACILLARY ANGIOMATOSIS caused by Bartonella henselae and bartonella quintana.
  • It is an angio-proliferative disease, characterized by neovascular skin lesions.
  • Visceral involvement with Bartonella quintana is also seen.
  • When the liver is involved, the disease is called Bacillary peliosis.
  • Bartonella henselae also causes cat scratch disease, which is caused by exposure to cat bite or scratch.
  • It is characterized by subacute painless regional lymphadenopathy.
  • Coxiella burnetti causes Q fever. Coxiella burnetii, no arthropod vector. Bacterium inhaled as aerosols from cattle/ sheep amniotic fluid. Presents with headache, cough, flulike symptoms, pneumonia, possibly in combination with hepatitis. Common cause of culture Θ endocarditis.
  • Campylobacter causes intestinal as well as extraintestinal manifestations. Major cause of bloody diarrhea, especially in children. Fecal-oral transmission through personto-person contact or via ingestion of undercooked contaminated poultry or meat, unpasteurized milk. Contact with infected animals (dogs, cats, pigs) is also a risk factor. Common antecedent to Guillain-Barré syndrome and reactive arthritis
  • Vibrio vulnificus causes toxin mediated diarrhea, as well as cellulitis on exposure to sea water. It causes two types of illness. The first is wound infection following contact of open wounds with sea water. The second type occurs in compromised hosts, particularly those with liver disease. Following ingestion of the vibrio, usually in oysters, it penetrates the gut mucosa without causing gastrointestinal manifestations and enters the bloodstream, rapidly leading to septicemia with high mortality.

choices.text: Exotoxin A and B: Inhibition of EF2

questions.text: Among the various virulence factors found in Pseudomonas, which of the following is the most important factor and what is its mechanism of action?
questions.solution:
Exotoxin A has a mechanism of action similar to that of the diphtheria toxin.

It also has A active B binding subunits and inhibits protein synthesis.

Good antibody response to exotoxin A is considered a favourable sign in severe infections with P. aeruginosa.

Virulence Factors of Pseudomonas:

  • Pili or fimbriae (the organ of attachment) and polar flagellum (mediates chemotactic motility to reach the host’s surface).
  • Toxin-mediated immune evasion and tissue injury:
  • Non-Diffusible toxins (e.g. exotoxins S, U, T, and Y)
  • Diffusible toxins: For example, exotoxin A, proteases, phospholipases, hemolysins, elastases, pyocyanin, etc.
  • Exotoxin A: This is the most important virulence factor of P. aeruginosa. It inhibits protein synthes
  • Pyo rubin
  • Pyo melanin
    • Alginate coat
    • Capsule
    • Biofilm formation
    • Wide temperature range
    • Mechanism of various bacteria toxins:
  • Inhibition of elongation factor 2:
    • Diphtheria toxin
    • Pseudomonas
  • Increase cAMP: Remember: 'CAEP'
    • Cholera
    • Anthrax
    • ETEC labile toxin
    • Pertussis
  • Increase cGMP:
    • ETEC stable toxin

questions.text: The test shown in the picture works on the principle of?
questions.solution:
Rapid antigen tests for COVID-19 typically utilize the lateral flow assay (LFA) method.

-Lateral Flow Assay (LFA):

  • In a lateral flow assay, a sample (such as nasal swab fluid) is placed on one end of a test strip that is coated with specific antibodies for the COVID-19 antigens (usually spike proteins).
  • The sample moves across the test strip by capillary action. If the target antigen (in this case, the SARS-CoV-2 antigen) is present, it binds to the antibodies and forms a visible line (such as a coloured band) at a specific spot on the test strip, indicating a positive result.

(B) Flow through assay: Similar to LFA, but the fluid passes through the entire membrane and is captured at a specific site. It is not as commonly used for COVID-19 antigen tests.

(C) Chemiluminescence Linked Immunoassay (CLIA): Involves a chemiluminescent reaction to detect the presence of an antigen or antibody. While CLIA is used in some COVID-19 testing platforms, it is not the principle behind most rapid antigen tests.

(D) ELISA (Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay): This test involves a more complex and time-consuming process that detects either antigens or antibodies. It is typically used for research or laboratory-based diagnostics, not rapid tests

questions.text: Choose the Non-acid fast staining organism
questions.solution:
• Acid-fast organisms are bacteria that retain their color after being treated with an acid-alcohol solution during a staining procedure, typically the Ziehl-Neelsen stain.
  • These organisms have a unique cell wall structure containing high concentrations of mycolic acids, which make them resistant to decolorization by acid-alcohol.
  • Acid fastness is due to high mycolic acid content in the cell wall.

Acid-Fast Organisms:

  1. Mycobacterium tuberculosis (causes tuberculosis)
  2. Mycobacterium leprae (causes leprosy)
  3. Nocardia species (causes nocardiosis)
  4. Corynebacterium species (certain species, like Corynebacterium diphtheriae in rare cases)
  5. Rhodococcus species (causes infections in immunocompromised patients)
  6. Head of a sperm is also acidic.

Key steps in Ziehl-Neelsen staining:

  1. Primary stain (Carbolfuchsin): The slide is first stained with carbolfuchsin, a red dye that penetrates the waxy cell wall of acid-fast organisms.
  2. Heat application: The slide is gently heated to facilitate the penetration of the dye.
  3. Decolorization (with acid-alcohol or H2SO4): The slide is treated with an acid-alcohol solution (usually containing about 3% to 5% H2SO4) to remove the stain from non-acid-fast organisms. Acid-fast bacteria resist decolorization due to their thick lipid-rich cell wall.
  4. Counterstaining: After decolorization, the slide is counterstained with methylene blue or brilliant green, which stains non-acid-fast organisms, allowing them to be differentiated.

questions.text: Which of the following need airborne contact preventing isolation in hospital?
questions.solution:
Measles is an airborne disease, meaning the virus can spread through the air via respiratory droplets, even when an infected person is not directly in the room. It requires airborne contact precautions to prevent transmission in a hospital setting.

Measles is a paramyxovirus - enveloped ssRNA virus

Only source of infection is a case of measles. Carriers are not known to occur.

Infective period - 4 days before and 5 days after appearance of rash

Infective material - secretion of nose, throat and respiratory tract

Age group - 6 months to 3year

C/F:

Prodromal stage - fever, coryza with sneezing and nasal discharge, redness of eye, lacrimation, photophobia

  • A day or two before the appearance of rash, Koplik spot appear on buccal mucosa opp 1st and 2nd lower molar tooth

Eruptive phase - maculopapular rash which begins behind the ear and spreads rapidly in a few hours over the face and neck extends down the body.

Post measle stage - Wt loss, growth retardation, diarrhea

Incorrect options:

  • (A) CJ disease (Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease): CJ disease is a prion disease and does not require airborne isolation. It requires standard precautions, and specific measures are focused on handling contaminated instruments and tissues.
  • (B) Nipah: Nipah virus is spread primarily through close contact with infected animals (especially bats) or people, and while it is highly contagious, it doesn't require airborne precautions, but droplet and contact precautions.
  • (D) Aseptic meningitis: Aseptic meningitis, typically caused by viral infections (such as enterovirus), requires droplet and contact precautions but not airborne precautions.

questions.text: Hepatitis B is which type of virus ?
questions.solution:
Hepatitis B virus is the most wide spread virus and the most important cause of viral hepatitis.

HBV belongs to Hepadna viridae

HBV is hepadnavirus type 1

Hepatitis B is the only hepatitis virus which has DNA. All other are RNA viruses

HBV contains two linear strands of DNA. One of the strands is incomplete and other is complete -Partially double stranded DNA.

HBV contains both DNA -dependent DNA polymerase and RNA dependent reverse transcriptase

Instead of DNA replication directly from DNA template, HBV relies on reverse transcriptase of minus strand DNA from A pregenomic RNA intermediate (Like retrovirus).

choices.text: Can be cultured on cell free medium
Bilateral infiltrates may be seen on XRC

questions.text: All are the features of Mycoplasma pneumonia except-
questions.solution:
Mycoplasma pneumoniae lacks a cell wall, so antibiotics that target the cell wall (like beta-lactams such as amoxicillin/clavulanate) are not effective. Instead, treatment for Mycoplasma pneumoniae infections typically involves antibiotics that inhibit protein synthesis, such as macrolides (e.g., azithromycin), tetracyclines (e.g., doxycycline), or fluoroquinolones (e.g., levofloxacin).

(A) Mycoplasma pneumoniae is a type of bacterium that lacks a cell wall, so it cannot be cultured on standard agar plates that require a cell wall. However, it can grow in special cell-free media, such as Eaton's agar or others designed specifically for mycoplasma.

(C): Bilateral infiltrates may be seen on X-ray –Mycoplasma pneumoniae infection often presents with atypical pneumonia, which may show bilateral infiltrates on chest X-ray, although consolidation is typically more subtle compared to bacterial pneumonia caused by organisms with cell walls.

(D): Antibodies useful in diagnosis –Diagnosis of Mycoplasma pneumoniae infection can be supported by detecting antibodies, particularly IgM antibodies in the patient's serum. Serologic tests, including complement fixation and PCR, are often used in the diagnosis of mycoplasma infections.

questions.text: Needle prick in a HCW, patient HBV reactive, anti-HBs >90mIU for HBV prophylaxis. What is to be done?
questions.solution:
Healthcare worker (HCW) has been exposed to a needle prick from a patient who is HBV reactive. However, the HCW's anti-HBs (Hepatitis B surface antibody) is >90 mIU, which indicates that the HCW has a protective titre against Hepatitis B.

  • Anti-HBs levels greater than 10 mIU/mL are considered protective. In this case, the HCW's anti-HBs level is much higher than the threshold of 10 mIU/mL, indicating immunity to Hepatitis B virus (HBV).
  • Prophylaxis for HBV (post-exposure) is typically required in healthcare workers (HCWs) who have not been previously vaccinated or who has anti-HBs titres are less than 10 mIU/mL.

(B): Hepatitis B vaccine and immunoglobulin - This would be recommended for HCWs who do not have protective antibody levels (anti-HBs <10 mIU/mL). Since the HCW already has a protective titre, this is not needed.

(C): Only immunoglobulin - This is used for post-exposure prophylaxis in individuals who have no immunity (no previous vaccination or very low anti-HBs levels). The HCW has a protective titre, so this is unnecessary.

(D): Only vaccine - This would be recommended for individuals who are not protected against HBV (no prior vaccination or low anti-HBs levels).

questions.text: Identify the medium used for the isolation of Salmonella Typhi.
questions.solution:
(A) Wilson-Blair medium:

  • Wilson-Blair medium is a selective and differential medium specifically used for the isolation of Salmonella typhi (the causative agent of typhoid fever).
  • This medium contains brilliant green, sodium thiosulfate, and bismuth salts, which suppress the growth of non-Salmonella organisms and allow Salmonella typhi to grow, often producing black colonies due to the reduction of bismuth salts by Salmonella.

(B) TCBS agar (Thiosulfate Citrate Bile Salts Sucrose agar):

  • TCBS agar is used primarily for the isolation of Vibrio species. It contains bile salts to inhibit the growth of Gram-positive bacteria and allows the growth of Vibrio species, which ferment sucrose to form yellow colonies.
  • It is not used for isolating Salmonella typhi.

(C) XLD agar (Xylose Lysine Deoxycholate agar):

  • XLD agar is a selective and differential medium used for the isolation of enteric pathogens like Salmonella and Shigella. While it can isolate Salmonella typhi, it is not as specific as Wilson-Blair medium. On XLD agar, Salmonella species typically appear as red colonies with or without black centers due to hydrogen sulfide production.
  • XLD agar is more commonly used for general Salmonella isolation, but Wilson-Blair is more specific for S. typhi.

(D) Mannitol salt agar:

  • Mannitol salt agar is a selective medium used for the isolation of Staphylococcus species, particularly Staphylococcus aureus, as it selects for salt-tolerant organisms. It contains 7.5% sodium chloride, which inhibits the growth of most bacteria, and mannitol as a fermentable carbohydrate, which causes the media to turn yellow if mannitol is fermented by Staphylococcus aureus.

questions.text: Adequacy of Pasteurisation is tested by which of the following test?
questions.solution:
Enzyme phosphatase is normally present in raw milk and is inactivated by pasteurization. Hence, this test is incorporated to check the adequacy of pasteurization.

The Phosphatase test is used to test the adequacy of pasteurization in dairy products (especially milk). Pasteurization involves heating the product to a certain temperature to kill harmful microorganisms without compromising the quality of the product.

The alkaline phosphatase enzyme is naturally present in raw milk. During pasteurization, this enzyme is inactivated by heat. If pasteurization is not done properly, phosphatase will still be active, indicating that the milk has not been sufficiently pasteurized.

The phosphatase test detects the presence of this enzyme to determine whether adequate pasteurization has been achieved. If the enzyme is present, it suggests that the milk was not heated to the required temperature or for the required time.

(A): Eijkman test: This test is not related to pasteurization but is historically used for testing the presence of toxins in food products, like in the case of botulism.

(B): Coliform test: This test detects the presence of coliform bacteria, which is an indicator of fecal contamination. While coliform testing is important for food safety, it is not specifically used to test pasteurization adequacy.

(C): Catalase test: This test is used to identify bacterial species based on their ability to produce the enzyme catalase. It is not used for testing pasteurization.

questions.text: There is an outbreak of encephalitis in a community, according to universal immunization schedule, the route of administration of the vaccine for the likely infection is:
questions.solution:
Vaccine for Japanese encephalitis is to be given subcutaneously and in the universal immunization program it is a live vaccine.

20.5 ml doses, one week apart, to children six to twelve months of age.

Booster doses are given one year later (0.5 mk) and at 6-10 years of age (1 ml).

Similar type of outbreak can be done by N meningitidis. Its vaccine is killed and can be given subcutaneously. But it is not part of the universal immunization program.

That's why the answer is D live subcutaneous.

Live attenuated vaccines: Adenovirus (nonattenuated, given to military recruits), typhoid (Ty21a, oral), polio (Sabin), varicella (chickenpox), smallpox, BCG, yellow fever, influenza (intranasal), MMR, rotavirus.

Killed or inactivated vaccine - Hepatitis A, Typhoid (Vi polysaccharide, intramuscular), Rabies, Influenza (intramuscular), Polio (SalK).

questions.text: Recent influenza A pandemic was due to
questions.solution:
Influenza is an RNA virus. It has segmented RNA. There are 8 segments. Till now many epidemics and pandemics have occurred due to various strains H5N1, H1N1 etc

Antigenic shift and antigenic drift occures in Influenza A virus.

Antigenic shift is a major change in antigenic structure and is responsible for pandemic.

Antigenic drift is a minor change in antigenic structure and is responsible for epidemic.

This virus is present in birds and animals (Swine). That's why it is also known as swine flu.

Recent influenza pandemic was due to H1N1.

Pandemics of modern times date from 1889. The most severe pandemic in recorded history occurred in 1918-19 ('Spanish flu'), during which over 200 million people were affected and more than 20 million perished. India suffered the most, with some 10 million deaths. An unusual feature of this pandemic was the very high rate of mortality among young adults. The next pandemic occurred in 1957 when the 'Asian strain' H2N2 originated in China and spread throughout the world within a short period. However, the mortality rate was low though it caused widespread morbidity. The Hong Kong H3N2 strain appearing in 1968 also caused a pandemic but it was much less severe.

questions.text: Which of the following is the culture medium used for legionella?
questions.solution:
Legionella is gram negative coccobacilli

Non capsulated.

Motile by polar or subpolar flagella.

Culture - Strict aerobe

Has fastidious requirements and grows on complex media such as buffered charcoal, yeast extract (BCYE) agar.

Nature habitats for Legionella are aquatic bodies, including lakes and streams.

Mode of transmission

  1. Aerosolization
  2. Aspiration
  3. Direct instillation in to the lung

The source of legionella is water

No animal reservoir exists

No carrier state was established.

(B): MacConkey agar: This is a selective medium for gram-negative bacteria, particularly enteric bacteria like Escherichia coli, and is not suitable for growing Legionella.

(C): Baird-Parker agar: This medium is selective for the isolation of Staphylococcus species, particularly Staphylococcus aureus, and is not used for Legionella.

(D): Sabouraud dextrose agar: This is a medium commonly used for the growth of fungi (e.g., yeasts and molds) and is not suitable for growing Legionella.

questions.text: A child is suffering from recurrent chronic infections with encapsulated bacteria. This is due to deficiency of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Children who suffer from recurrent chronic infections with encapsulated bacteria often have a deficiency in IgG2, which is one of the subclasses of IgG antibodies.

  • IgG2 plays a crucial role in the immune defense against capsulated bacteria, such as Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, and Neisseria meningitidis.
  • These bacteria have a polysaccharide capsule that helps them evade the immune system, and IgG2 is particularly effective in opsonizing these encapsulated organisms, making them easier to clear by phagocytes.
  • IgG deficiency: When there is a deficiency in IgG2, the immune system has difficulty mounting an effective response against encapsulated bacteria, leading to recurrent infections in children, especially with organisms that rely on the capsular structure to evade immune detection.
  • An autoimmune disorder causes your immune system to attack your own healthy cells by mistake which lead to serious health problems.

Incorrect options:

Option (A) IgG1: IgG1 is important for responses to protein antigens and is the most prevalent IgG subclass in the blood. It helps with antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC) and neutralization of viruses and toxins.

Option (C) IgG3: IgG3 is involved in activation of the complement system and is important in the immune response to viruses and extracellular bacteria. A deficiency in IgG3 would lead to increased susceptibility to infections.

Option (D) IgG4: IgG4 is associated with immune tolerance and is the least involved in fighting infections.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed to have scrub typhus developed high grade fever and cough. What is the treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
Scrub typhus is caused by the bacterium Orientia tsutsugamushi and is typically treated with antibiotics. The recommended first-line treatment for scrub typhus is doxycycline, which is effective against Orientia tsutsugamushi.

C.IV Doxycycline plus Azithromycin: This combination therapy is commonly used for severe cases of scrub typhus. Doxycycline is the mainstay of treatment, targeting the Orientia tsutsugamushi bacteria. Azithromycin is often added in severe cases or when there is concern about resistance to doxycycline. Azithromycin can provide additional coverage and may be preferred in pregnant patients or those who cannot tolerate doxycycline.

Reference: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, National Center for Emerging and Zoonotic Infectious Diseases (NCEZID), Division of Vector-Borne Diseases (DVBD)

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with fever and severe pain in upper right abdominal quadrant. He gives a history of bloody diarrhoea 3 weeks back. Abdominal CT shows a lesion in the right lobe of liver with ragged edges, multiple septations and heterogeneous densities. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Given the clinical presentation of fever, severe pain in the upper right abdominal quadrant, history of bloody diarrhea, and the findings on abdominal CT showing a lesion in the right lobe of the liver with ragged edges, multiple septations, and heterogeneous densities, the most likely diagnosis is Amoebic liver abscess.

(A) Hydatid cyst: A hydatid cyst in the liver is caused by Echinococcus species, and while it can cause abdominal pain and discomfort, the CT appearance is typically more well-circumscribed with a smooth, fluid-filled cavity and daughter cysts.

(B) Pyogenic liver abscess: Pyogenic liver abscesses are usually caused by bacterial infections, often from biliary tract disease or hematogenous spread. They typically present with single or multiple abscesses, but the CT findings would usually show smooth-walled, round or oval lesions rather than the ragged edges and multiple septations seen in amoebic abscesses. Pyogenic abscesses also usually don't have a history of bloody diarrhea unless there is a complicating infection.

(D) Hepatic adenoma: A hepatic adenoma is a benign liver tumor, and while it can cause abdominal pain, it does not present with fever or bloody diarrhea. Additionally, on CT, a hepatic adenoma would appear as a well-defined mass, usually homogeneous in density, without the ragged edges or septations seen in an abscess.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents with a "slapped cheek" rash and a lacy rash on his trunk and extremities. He had a mild fever a few days prior. What is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation described - a "slapped cheek" rash followed by a lacy rash on the trunk and extremities - is highly characteristic of erythema infectiosum, commonly known as fifth disease. This condition is caused by Parvovirus B19.

  • Slapped cheek rash: This is the hallmark sign of fifth disease caused by Parvovirus B19. The rash typically begins on the cheeks, giving a characteristic red, flushed appearance, often described as a "slapped cheek" appearance.
  • Lacy, maculopapular rash: After the slapped cheek appearance, a lacy rash may appear on the trunk and extremities. This rash is often more pronounced in a proximal-to-distal pattern (starting on the body and moving out to the arms and legs).

(A): Human herpesvirus 6 (HHV-6): This virus causes roseola (sixth disease), which presents with a high fever followed by a rash that begins on the trunk and may spread to the extremities. However, the rash typically starts after the fever resolves.

(B): Rubella virus: Rubella (German measles) presents with a maculopapular rash that typically starts on the face and spreads downwards.

(C): Measles virus: Measles presents with a high fever, Koplik spots (white spots in the mouth), and a morbilliform (red, blotchy) rash that begins at the hairline and spreads downward.

questions.text: An adult man came with a clinical condition shown in the image. Gram negative diplococci found in Gram stain. What is the treatment?
questions.solution:
Based on the information provided, the presence of gram-negative diplococci suggests a likely infection caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae, which is the bacterium responsible for gonorrhea. The recommended treatment for gonorrhea typically includes:

Cefixime: This is a cephalosporin antibiotic that is often used as a first-line treatment for uncomplicated gonorrhea infections.

While Azithromycin and Doxycycline are also used in certain contexts, they are generally not the primary treatments for gonorrhea, especially in cases where Neisseria gonorrhoeae is suspected.

Thus, the most appropriate treatment option from the list you provided is:

  1. Cefixime

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK538213/

questions.text: Broad base budding yeasts seen in
questions.solution:
Blastomycosis is caused by the fungus Blastomyces dermatitidis, which is characterized by broad-based budding yeasts. These yeasts typically measure 8 to 15 micrometers in diameter and have thick, double-contoured walls, making them distinctive under microscopic examination. This morphology is specifically noted in the diagnosis of blastomycosis.

The search results confirm that the broad-based budding yeast forms are a key diagnostic feature of blastomycosis, as highlighted in multiple sources discussing the characteristics and identification of Blastomyces.

Overview of Other Options:

  1. Histoplasmosis: Caused by Histoplasma capsulatum, which appears as small intracellular yeasts within macrophages, not broad-based budding yeasts.
  2. Candidiasis: Caused by Candida species, which can form yeast and pseudohyphal forms but do not exhibit broad-based budding.
  3. Coccidiomycosis: Caused by Coccidioides immitis, which produces spherules filled with endospores rather than broad-based budding yeasts.

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5657236/

questions.text: A child presented with perianal itching. Swab specimen Shown in the image. What is the diagnosis
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical presentation of perianal itching in a child and the microscopic image showing pinworm eggs, the correct diagnosis is:

  1. Enterobius (Pinworms)

Enterobius vermicularis, commonly known as pinworms, is a common intestinal parasite that can cause perianal itching, especially in children. The female pinworms migrate to the perianal area at night to lay their eggs, which can be detected by the "tape test" method.

The microscopic image likely shows the characteristic oval-shaped, flattened pinworm eggs with a translucent shell. This finding, along with the typical symptom of perianal itching, confirms the diagnosis of pinworm infection.

Overview of Other Options:

  1. Ascaris: Ascaris lumbricoides is a large roundworm that can cause intestinal obstruction but is not typically associated with perianal itching.
  2. Trichiura: Trichuris trichiura (whipworm) can cause chronic dysentery but is not a common cause of perianal itching.
  3. Ancylostoma: Ancylostoma species (hookworms) primarily cause cutaneous larva migrans and intestinal blood loss but are not associated with perianal itching.

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2647235/
